comments.body: this should probably be namespace (NPY_MIN is already used for something else ...) or ifdef protected, this can be defined by system headers (but I guess it should only be a redefinition warning)

2013/12/3 Julian Taylor notifications@github.com

> In numpy/core/blasdot/_dotblas.c:
> 
> > @@ -22,66 +24,147 @@
> > 
> >  static PyArray_DotFunc *oldFunctions[NPY_NTYPES];
> > 
> > +#define MIN(a, b)   ((a) < (b) ? (a) : (b))
> 
> this should probably be namespace (NPY_MIN is already used for something
> else ...) or ifdef protected, this can be defined by system headers (but I
> guess it should only be a redefinition warning)

System headers on an ISO C-compliant system may not define a non-standard
macro in standard headers; any macro identifier must either be listed in
the standard, be defined in a non-standard header, or be prefixed with an
underscore (which is why I've been removing identifiers matching "_[A-Z]"
from the NumPy codebase: those are off-limits).

Given the headers that are included by this module, we'd be protecting
against broken C environments, broken BLAS headers or our own mistakes.
all of which can happen, e.g. of distantly related headers sys/param.h and lapacke_utils.h define MIN on my system.

Ok, on mine too. One of those headers actually says copyright Intel 2010 instead of Ignorance Corp 1983...

Still, the worst that can happen in not too-broken environments is that `MIN` is redefined and a warning is issued. If we ever move to compiling with `-Werror` (unlikely) then this can be changed.
